## Description {#details}

LLVM Basic Block Representation.

This represents a single basic block in LLVM. A basic block is simply a container of instructions that execute sequentially. Basic blocks are Values because they are referenced by instructions such as branches and switch tables. The type of a <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/basicblock">BasicBlock</a> is &quot;Type::LabelTy&quot; because the basic block represents a label to which a branch can jump.

A well formed basic block is formed of a list of non-terminating instructions followed by a single terminator instruction. Terminator instructions may not occur in the middle of basic blocks, and must terminate the blocks. The <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/basicblock">BasicBlock</a> class allows malformed basic blocks to occur because it may be useful in the intermediate stage of constructing or modifying a program. However, the verifier will ensure that basic blocks are &quot;well formed&quot;.

Definition at line 60 of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/ir/basicblock-h">BasicBlock.h</a>.

### dropAllReferences() {#ab7844ce6d5301816e9a7bc21d7f08ef2}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype="void BasicBlock::dropAllReferences ()">
Cause all subinstructions to &quot;let go&quot; of all the references that said subinstructions are maintaining.

This allows one to &#39;delete&#39; a whole class at a time, even though there may be circular references... first all references are dropped, and all use counts go to zero. Then everything is delete&#39;d for real. Note that no operations are valid on an object that has &quot;dropped all references&quot;, except operator delete.

Declaration at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/ir/basicblock-h/#l00584">584</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/ir/basicblock-h">BasicBlock.h</a>, definition at line 476 of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/sandboxir/basicblock-cpp">BasicBlock.cpp</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

### flushTerminatorDbgRecords() {#a7a7dc3732891611f559b06951a6ee85a}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype="void BasicBlock::flushTerminatorDbgRecords ()">
Eject any debug-info trailing at the end of a block.

DbgRecords can transiently be located &quot;off the end&quot; of a block if the blocks terminator is temporarily removed. Once a terminator is re-inserted this method will move such DbgRecords back to the right place (ahead of the terminator).

Declaration at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/ir/basicblock-h/#l00146">146</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/ir/basicblock-h">BasicBlock.h</a>, definition at line 739 of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/sandboxir/basicblock-cpp">BasicBlock.cpp</a>.

### getFirstNonPHI() {#a05695d7068e19f1799ed15ed7523a957}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>Instruction &#42; BasicBlock::getFirstNonPHI () const</>}>
Returns a pointer to the first instruction in this block that is not a <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/phinode">PHINode</a> instruction.

When adding instructions to the beginning of the basic block, they should be added before the returned value, not before the first instruction, which might be PHI. Returns 0 is there&#39;s no non-PHI instruction.

Deprecated in favour of getFirstNonPHIIt, which returns an iterator that preserves some debugging information.

Declaration at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/ir/basicblock-h/#l00287">287</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/ir/basicblock-h">BasicBlock.h</a>, definition at line 367 of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/sandboxir/basicblock-cpp">BasicBlock.cpp</a>.

### getFirstNonPHIIt() {#a362b5e6097732cbc0d2fb555a1f73400}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>BasicBlock::const&#95;iterator BasicBlock::getFirstNonPHIIt () const</>}>
Returns an iterator to the first instruction in this block that is not a <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/phinode">PHINode</a> instruction.

When adding instructions to the beginning of the basic block, they should be added before the returned value, not before the first instruction, which might be PHI. Returns <a href="#a0b4e7bee9b8575cc7db73329f1a561bd">end()</a> if there&#39;s no non-PHI instruction.

Avoid unwrapping the iterator to an Instruction&#42; before inserting here, as important debug-info is preserved in the iterator.

### splitBasicBlock() {#a52c990590792c91dd20b6d45acebe359}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>BasicBlock &#42; BasicBlock::splitBasicBlock (<a href="#a98c0a84a5dfa8bce341c829709f171e5">iterator</a> I, <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/aarch64/aarch64promoteconstant-cpp/#a90f8350fecae261c25be85d38b451bff">const</a> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/twine">Twine</a> &amp; BBName=&quot;&quot;, bool Before=false)</>}>
Split the basic block into two basic blocks at the specified instruction.

If <code>Before</code> is true, splitBasicBlockBefore handles the block splitting. Otherwise, execution proceeds as described below.

Note that all instructions BEFORE the specified iterator stay as part of the original basic block, an unconditional branch is added to the original BB, and the rest of the instructions in the BB are moved to the new BB, including the old terminator. The newly formed basic block is returned. This function invalidates the specified iterator.

Note that this only works on well formed basic blocks (must have a terminator), and <code>&#39;I&#39;</code> must not be the end of instruction list (which would cause a degenerate basic block to be formed, having a terminator inside of the basic block).

Also note that this doesn&#39;t preserve any passes. To split blocks while keeping loop information consistent, use the SplitBlock utility function.

Declaration at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/ir/basicblock-h/#l00614">614</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/ir/basicblock-h">BasicBlock.h</a>, definition at line 599 of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/sandboxir/basicblock-cpp">BasicBlock.cpp</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

### splitBasicBlock() {#a2bc5caaabd6841e4ab97237ebcaeb86d}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>BasicBlock &#42; llvm::BasicBlock::splitBasicBlock (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/instruction">Instruction</a> &#42; I, <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/aarch64/aarch64promoteconstant-cpp/#a90f8350fecae261c25be85d38b451bff">const</a> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/twine">Twine</a> &amp; BBName=&quot;&quot;, bool Before=false)</>}
  labels = {["inline"]}>

Definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/ir/basicblock-h/#l00616">616</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/ir/basicblock-h">BasicBlock.h</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

### splitBasicBlockBefore() {#a30def825db848cba7fe11baa870b978f}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>BasicBlock &#42; BasicBlock::splitBasicBlockBefore (<a href="#a98c0a84a5dfa8bce341c829709f171e5">iterator</a> I, <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/aarch64/aarch64promoteconstant-cpp/#a90f8350fecae261c25be85d38b451bff">const</a> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/twine">Twine</a> &amp; BBName=&quot;&quot;)</>}>
Split the basic block into two basic blocks at the specified instruction and insert the new basic blocks as the predecessor of the current block.

This function ensures all instructions AFTER and including the specified iterator <code>I</code> are part of the original basic block. All Instructions BEFORE the iterator <code>I</code> are moved to the new BB and an unconditional branch is added to the new BB. The new basic block is returned.

Note that this only works on well formed basic blocks (must have a terminator), and <code>&#39;I&#39;</code> must not be the end of instruction list (which would cause a degenerate basic block to be formed, having a terminator inside of the basic block). <code>&#39;I&#39;</code> cannot be a iterator for a <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/phinode">PHINode</a> with multiple incoming blocks.

Also note that this doesn&#39;t preserve any passes. To split blocks while keeping loop information consistent, use the SplitBlockBefore utility function.

Declaration at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/ir/basicblock-h/#l00638">638</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/ir/basicblock-h">BasicBlock.h</a>, definition at line 630 of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/sandboxir/basicblock-cpp">BasicBlock.cpp</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

### validateInstrOrdering() {#a9458ac6ff40d62e47321f8681cc23d54}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype="void BasicBlock::validateInstrOrdering () const">
Asserts that instruction order numbers are marked invalid, or that they are in ascending order.

In asserts builds, this checks the numbering.

This is constant time if the ordering is invalid, and linear in the number of instructions if the ordering is valid. Callers should be careful not to call this in ways that make common operations O(n^2). For example, it takes O(n) time to assign order numbers to instructions, so the order should be validated no more than once after each ordering to ensure that transforms have the same algorithmic complexity when asserts are enabled as when they are disabled.

In non-asserts builds, it is defined as a no-op inline function in BasicBlock.h.

Declaration at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/ir/basicblock-h/#l00736">736</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/ir/basicblock-h">BasicBlock.h</a>, definition at line 1165 of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/sandboxir/basicblock-cpp">BasicBlock.cpp</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

</SectionDefinition>

### AdjustBlockAddressRefCount() {#a5a1fd63db7827caba1d32a6505ae8997}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype="void llvm::BasicBlock::AdjustBlockAddressRefCount (int Amt)"
  labels = {["inline"]}>
Increment the internal refcount of the number of BlockAddresses referencing this <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/basicblock">BasicBlock</a> by <code>Amt</code>.

This is almost always 0, sometimes one possibly, but almost never 2, and inconceivably 3 or more.

### spliceDebugInfo() {#adabab3e391aec9a349e44767635cf2f2}
